Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: External Magnetic Field Assisted Laser Metal Deposition of Highly Oriented Crystalline Ni-Based Alloys

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Directionally solidified nickel-based alloys are widely used as structural materials under extreme environments, where high-temperature strength, thermal creep resistance, and anti-oxidation properties are required. Although additive manufacturing (AM) has become more competitive in manufacturing metal components in recent years, the existing AM methods are still inadequate to fabricate directionally solidified alloys because of the obstacles in controlling crystal nucleation and growth orientations. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project investigates fundamental research enabling laser metal deposition to produce highly oriented crystal metals with the help of magnetic fields. It effectively pushes the limit of AM methods to manufacturing high-end structural parts for a number of industries including aerospace, power generation, and automotive, with shorter product development times and enhanced performance, and at affordable costs.

The research objective is to investigate the fundamental science of magnetic field effects on crystal orientation of Ni-based alloys in a laser metal deposition process. With the proper design and process parameters, this project's AM method is expected to mitigate or even eliminate the columnar to equiaxed transition phenomenon, and thus it can produce highly oriented crystalline Ni-based alloys with controllable orientation and improved mechanical properties. Crystal orientation control is realized by applying a strong static magnetic field in laser metal deposition, so that the angle between the easy magnetization axis and the preferred growth direction in in line with that between magnetic field and thermal flux. Comprehensive mechanical property measurements and microstructure characterization will be carried out to validate the effectiveness of the method. The crystal orientation control mechanism will provide unprecedented insight on developing a new generation of high performance alloys with controllable microstructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, experiments have been designed and conducted to demonstrate the feasibility of obtaining highly oriented texture of a Ni-based alloy through laser metal deposition (LMD) process by applying an external magnetic field. Inconel 718 samples are deposited without and with a 1.8 T transverse magnetic field. The elemental distribution, grain morphology, and texture are compared carefully for both cases. It is shown that under both conditions, the dendritic structure is similar, and the grain size seems to be hardly affected by the application of the strong magnetic field.

More importantly, it is found that the magnetic field significantly affects the nucleation and solidification behavior of Inconel 718 during LMD. When the external magnetic field direction and heat flux direction are placed in a perpendicular manner, the orientation of nucleus will be more strictly constrained by both the heat flux and magnetic field, resulting in a highly oriented texture. By applying a transverse magnetic field, the grain boundary misorientation angle significantly decreases from 32 to 19 degree. Meanwhile, it is discovered that without the magnetic field, a large number of grains deviate from the dominant <001> direction, while with a strong external magnetic field during LMD, the number of grains deviated from the <001> direction is significantly reduced.

The project has provided the research training opportunities for graduate students at the University of Cincinnati (UC). In sequence, three graduate students have been partially supported by this project. The project has contributed to the development and offering of the first graduate level course dedicated to additive manufacturing (AM) at UC, namely, MECH 7080 “Metal Additive Manufacturing – Principles and Process Modeling”. The course has been offered every academic year since Spring 2018. The project has also contributed to the establishment of a new graduate program, “Master of Engineering in Additive Manufacturing”, at UC.

The project results have been disseminated to (1) industry by making presentations to companies such as GE Aviation and Mazak USA; and (2) research community by publishing with leading technical journals. The method proposed in this project has the potential to effectively push the limit of AM techniques to manufacturing high-performance structural components for industry. With the successful proof of concept, both the industry and the research community have become aware of this novel texture control method. In the future, the fundamental mechanism should be further investigated, and the fine tuning of process configuration should be conducted.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2019
Modified by: Jing Shi

It is shown that under both conditions, the dendritic structure is similar, and the grain size seems to be hardly affected by the application of the strong magnetic field. When the external magnetic field direction and heat flux direction are placed in a perpendicular manner, the orientation of nucleus will be more strictly constrained by both the heat flux and magnetic field, resulting in a highly oriented texture. By applying a transverse magnetic field, the grain boundary misorientation angle significantly decreases from 32 to 19 degree.
